comments.commentBody: Ethics DOES matter.  The university president and the one before him should NOT get a severence or pension on this

"After spending 2002 as a graduate assistant, McQueary was bumped up to an administrative assistant with the football program."

Why didn't McQueary rescue that ten year old child who was being raped by Sandusky? He certainly deserves to be fired and arrested. He saw the rape in and did nothing!
Somehow this means nothing; they need to do jail time.
I also want to know why Mike McQueary didn't go to the Police...I just can't imagine not going to the police if you see a child being raped.  I think he should be dismissed also.

#10

Due process was followed, Paterno knew the Board could dismiss him at any time.

GOODBYE! Don't let the door hit you in your unscrupulous face. Given what we know so far, which is quite extensive, it is clear he was aware of problems and did nothing. Not an example, not a leader. Seriously, from what we now know some of these people should go to jail. The measure of a man (person) is what they do when nobody else is looking. He thought he could brush this aside via the might of position and the infectious power of football in higher education. Adios

There is a lesson here.  Honorable men may differ about a lot of things, but the moral imperative to immediately report to police a 50 year old man's rape of a 10 year old boy is not one of them.  If you see or learn of such an event, you must call 911.  Don't first call your boss, don't first call your lawyer, don't even call your mother.  Call 911.  Your failure to do so will justly condemn you to universal ignominy, no matter how compelling your other lifetime achievements might be.  Sorry, Coach, but that's the way it is.  And that's the way it should be.
a witch hunt, circa the 21st century...

IT IS ENTIRELY INACCURATE FOR ANYONE TO SAY THAT JOE PATERNO DID NOT REPORT THIS MATTER TO THE POLICE.

Once Paterno learned of the allegations they were reported the following day to Gary Schultz, who was the administrative head of the Penn State Police Department. As Penn State's V.P. for Business and Finance, Schultz was the administrative equivalent of a state Attorney General with jurisdiction over a State Police Department.

I know people consider Paterno to be the de facto benevolent dictator of State College, but the fact remains that he is not the guy at the top of the organizational chart. His bosses were Curley, Schultz, the President of the University. He followed proper protocol. It was not his job to put a tail on Sandusky 24 hours a day or doing anything else.

Joe Pa! We love you so much, but you had to go. It's a matter of principle, honor, trust, and integrity. Live out your days in peace with your family. Take a trip to Italy. Let it all go, my friend. Love you so much!
Great.  Clearly a certain type of organization man of a certain age views the victims as expendable to whatever organization is involved.  Isn't that true Bishop Paternor, Archbishop Spanier?

How quickly we rush to judgment in the belief we know all the facts. We may know what the grand jury reports said --they're verbatin, but nobody has gone to trial yet so the FACTS are still slippery. So far, it's ben trial by news media, print, TV and radio. I can't accept that as the final judgment on Paterno, not after his reputation over so many years that if he were a bas...d something would have surfaced before now.
Wow...that happened FAR too fast. As others have asked: "what ever happened to due process [our country was founded upon.]" Disgusting.

Absolutely the right thing for the Board to do!

Paterno's comments re it being the greatest tragedy of HIS life were offensive and grossly disingenuous.

Clearly, Paterno regrets that the cover-up was exposed. It is also incontrovertible that Paterno made a conscious, continuous choice to protect his "Program" as opposed to the abused young victims.

Shame on Paterno and all those involved in this morally reprehensible - and possibly criminal - institutional scheme.

ISIDE NOTE: Instead of focusing on College Football "Programs" and sports "Legacies" at Universities, how about highlighting, celebrating and INCREASING the pay and stature of great teachers??

It needed to be done. McQueary needs to be fired, too, for he failed to report to outside authorities (police, child protective services) a crime he WITNESSED as required by mandated reporting laws.

Paterno was head coach for 46 years and worked at Penn State for 61. He had a reputation for being a class act. Now all of that hard work is gone. He will be remembered as the man who looked the other way while a serial pedophile was on campus destroying young boys' lives, the man who was at the center of the biggest scandal in the history of college sports.

He should have resigned the minute of this going public, but he really should have reported this to the police. What is more important?  Children being hurt for life, or football?  This man is a scum bag, no matter what he has achieved...He is into Joe, not anyone else...sad, very sad.....

Thank Goodness! Penn State Board made the right decision - How about everyone start focusing on the victims. Joe Paterno IS NOT a VICTIM, HE was/is part of the problem!  As this plays out it will get uglier and the truth will eventually and fully come out.  It will not be pretty for any of the Penn State administrators.   Paterno, the highest paid employee of Penn State, needs to realize that he is not above the laws of morality. This might be a crisis for Penn State and ESPN but for the rest of us it absolutely was the correct thing to do...

A question for the Paterno apologists:
What "due process" did those young boys get?

if you really want to be sick, read the grand jury report that is floating about on the web.... beyond anything the papers or cables can report..... this is sick beyond belief... cops knew about it and did nothing. this is going to blow up in many ways beyond the university..... another crack in the wall....

Mr. Anderson (#4), your comments are very helpful and much appreciated. At the same time, your own website acknowledges most perpetrators have a history of being the victims of sexual abuse themselves. While I have no doubt you are correct in acknowledging most who are abused do not themselves become abusers, the situation is a bit more complicated than the wording of your current post acknowledges (in my opinion). That is, perpetrators more often than not were themselves victims at one time. This is a fact that often gets lost in the mix in our emotional reactions to the violation of children.

I'm sorry that JoePa's career at Penn State has come to an end in this manner.  He has done so much for the university and the football program.  To the critics on this list, his sin was that he did not check back with Curley and Shultz on what they had done about the incident and he did not force these individuals to report the incident to the police.  Obviously, he and McQueary thought that the university administrators would do "the right thing" and report it.  The university administrators did not and perhaps all of you should take your anger out on them since none of them did their job.

Paterno should be out!  ""He who passively accepts evil is as much involved in it as he who helps to perpetrate it.  He who accepts evil without protesting against it is really cooperating with it."  (MLK, quoted by Bob Herbert, NYT 1/18/07)
This horrible scandal dwarfs any other sports scandal..........EVER!!
Penn State is a great school.. this doesn't help them..the trusties acted way to fast

Why is McQueary still employed by Penn State.  He is the one who SAW an adult raping a child in the shower, and he just walked out rather than stop it???  Who cares that he went to talk to his daddy and then to Paterno the next day?  What kind of human being watches what McQueary watched and does nothing to stop it?  McQueary is far more culpable than Paterno.
